<tei-TEI data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" data-origname="TEI" data-origatts="xmlns:xi xmlns">

           <tei-title data-origname="title">Viaje de Monsíenr Acárete du Biscay desde Buenos Aires hasta el Perú</tei-title>
        </tei-titleStmt>

           <tei-p data-origname="p" data-empty=""/>
        </tei-publicationStmt>

 <tei-text data-origname="text">
   <tei-body data-origname="body">
      <tei-div data-origname="div">
         <tei-head data-origname="head">Viaje de Monsieur <tei-name type="person" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Acárete du Biscay</tei-name> desde <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos Aires</tei-name> hasta el <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Perú</tei-name></tei-head>
      </tei-div>
      <tei-div data-origname="div">
         <tei-p data-origname="p">
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Salí de <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos Aires</tei-name>y tomé el camino de <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Córdoba</tei-name>, de-
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>jando <tei-reg data-origname="reg">a</tei-reg> <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Santa Fe</tei-name> <tei-reg data-origname="reg">a</tei-reg> mí derecha, de cuyo lugar, <tei-reg data-origname="reg">he</tei-reg> aquí una relación:
         </tei-p>
         
         <tei-p data-origname="p">
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Es una población española dependiente de <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos Aires</tei-name>
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>siendo el comandante un mero teniente, quien nada hace sin
         orden del Gobernador de<tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos Aires</tei-name>. Es una pequeña
         población, compuesta de 25 casas, sin murallas, fortifica-
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ciones, ni guarnición, distante de <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos Aires</tei-name> 80 leguas al
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Norte. Situada sobre el <tei-reg data-origname="reg">Río</tei-reg> de la Plata, buques grandes po-
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>drían llegar hasta allí, si no fuese por un gran banco que obs-
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>truye el paso, un poco mas arriba de <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos Aires</tei-name>. Sin em-
         <tei-pb data-origname="pb" data-empty=""/>
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>bargo, es un punto muy ventajoso, porque es el único paso
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>que hay al <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Paraguay</tei-name> desde el Perú, Chile y Tucuman, y en
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>cierto modo es el depósito de los efectos que de allí se es-
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>traen especialmente de la yerba, de la cual ya he hablado,
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>sin la cual no pueden estar en aquellas Provincias.
         </tei-p>
         
         <tei-p data-origname="p">
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>El suelo, aqui como en Buenos Aires, es bueno y fértil,
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>y el pueblo, no difiriendo en nada remarcable de lo que ya
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>hemos observado en Buenos Aires, le dejo y prosigo
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>mi viaje. Cuéntanse 140 leguas desde Buenos Aires hasta Cór-
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>doba, y por razón de ser algunas partes del camino en lar-
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>gos trechos despoblado, me proveí á mi salida de aquello
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>que me dijeron precisarla. Partí, pues, llevando por guia
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>un salvaje, con tres caballos y tres muías, algunas para lle-
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>var mi equipaje y el resto para mudar en el camino cuando
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>el montado se me cansase.
         </tei-p>
         <tei-p data-origname="p">
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Desde Buenos Aires hasta el Rio deLucan (1) y aun hasta
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>el Rio Recife (2) á 30 leguas del pueblo, pasé varias habi-
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>taciones y chacras cultivadas por los españoles, pero mas
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>allá del Recife hast i el Rio Saladillo, no vi ninguna. Obser-
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>varé de paso, que tanto estos rios como los demás de las
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>provincias de Buenos Aires, Paraguay y Tucuman, que de-
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>saguan en el Rio de la Plata, son vadeables á caballo, pero
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>cuando las lluvias ó cualesquier accidente los hace crecer,
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>el viajero se vé obligado á atravesarlos nadando, sino ó
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>colocarse sobre un bulto en forma de balsa que un salva-
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>je pasa tirando al lado opuesto. No sabia yo nadar, y por
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>lo mismo tuve dos ó tres veces que acudir á este espedien-
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>te cuando no encontraba paso. El modo de verificarlo
         <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>era este: mi indio mataba un toro, desollábalo, y rellenando
         <tei-pb data-origname="pb" data-empty=""/>
         </tei-p>
         <tei-p data-origname="p">
         1. Lujan.
         2. Arrecifes.
         </tei-p>
      </tei-div>
   </tei-body>
 </tei-text>
</tei-TEI>

 <tei-text data-origname="text">
   <tei-body data-origname="body">
      <tei-div data-origname="div">
         <tei-head data-origname="head">Monſieur Acarete du Biscay's Journey from Buenos Ayres to Peru.</tei-head>
      </tei-div>
      <tei-div data-origname="div">
         <tei-p data-origname="p">
            <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>I Left Buenos Ayres, and took the Road I <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>to Cordoua, leaving Santa Fe on my <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>right hand, of which place take this ac<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>count, 'tis a Spaniſh Settlement dependant <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>upon Buenos Ayres, the Commander is <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>no more than a Lieutenant, and does no<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>thing but by order from the Governor <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>of Buenos Ayres. 'Tis a little place con<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>taining 25 Houſes, without any Walls, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Fortifications, or Garriſon, diſtant 80 <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Leagues from Buenos Ayres Northward, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Situate upon the River de la Plata, large <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Veſſels might come up to it, were it not <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>for a great bank that obstructs the pas<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>sage a little above Buenos Ayres. Ne<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>vertheleſs 'tis a very advantageous Poſt, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>because 'tis the only passage from Peru, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Chili and Tucuman to Paraguay, and in a <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>manner the Magazine of the Commodi<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ties
         </tei-p>
      </tei-div>
      <tei-div data-origname="div"><tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ties drawn from thence, particularly that <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Herb already ſpoken of, which they <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>cannot be without in thoſe Provinces. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>The Soil is as good and Fertile here as <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>at Buenos Ayres; and the Town having <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>nothing remarkably different from what <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>has been observ'd of Buenos Ayres, I <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>leave it, and proceed upon my Jour<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ney. 'Tis counted 140 Leagues from <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Buenos Ayres to Cordoua, and becauſe <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ſome parts of the Road are uninhabited <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>for a long way together; I ſurnished <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>my ſelf at my departure with what I <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>was inform'd I ſhould ſtand in need <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>of; ſo I ſet out having a Savage for my <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Guide, with Three Horſes and Three <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Mules, ſome to carry my Baggage, and <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>the reſt to change upon the way when <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>that I rid upon was tired. 
<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>From Buenos Ayres, to the River Lu<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>can, and even as far as the River Recife, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>30 Leagues, I pass’d by several Habita<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>tions and Farms cultivated by the Spani<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ards, but beyond Recife to the River <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Salladillo, I ſaw none. Let it be obſer<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ved by the way, that theſe Rivers as well <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>as all the reſt in the Provinces of Buenos <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Ayres, Paraguay and Tucuman, that fall <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>into the River de la Plata are fordable <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>on Horſe-back; but when the Rains or <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>any</tei-p>
</tei-div>
<tei-div data-origname="div">
<tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>any other accident ſwells them, a Tra<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>veller muſt either ſwim over, or elſe get <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>upon a bundle in the nature of a raft, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>which a Savage hawls over to the other <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ſide. I could not Swim, and ſo was <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>forc'd to make uſe of this expedient <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>twice or thrice when I could not find a <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Ford. The way was this, my Indian <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>kill'd a Wild Bull, flead the Hide off, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ſtuffed it with ſtraw, and ty'd it up in <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>a great bundle with thongs of the ſame <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Hide, upon which I plac'd my ſelf with <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>my Baggage ; he ſwam over hawling me <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>after him by a Cord ty'd to the bundle, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>and then he repaſs'd and ſwam my Horſes <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>and Mules over to me.
<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>All the Country between the River <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Recife and Salladillo, tho' uninhabited, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>abounds in Cattle and all ſorts of Fruit <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>trees, except Walnut and Chesnut-trees; <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>there are whole Woods of Nectarine-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Trees, Three or Four Leagues in compaſs, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>that bear excellent Fruit, which they <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>not only eat raw, but bake them, or dry <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>them in the Sun, to keep, as we in France <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>do Prunes: They ſeldom uſe any other <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>than the Wood of this Tree for common <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>firing at Buenos Ayres, and thereabouts. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>The Savages that dwell in theſe Parts are <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>diſtinguiſh'd into two sorts, those that <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>volun-</tei-p>
</tei-div>
<tei-div data-origname="div"><tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>voluntarily ſubmit to the Spaniards are <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>call’d Panpiſtas, the reſt Serranos, both <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>cloathed with Skins, but the laſt ſet up <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>on the Panpiſtas as their mortal Enemies <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>wherever they meet with them. All <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Fight on Horſe-back, either with Lances <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>pointed with Iron or Bones ſharpen'd, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>or else with Bows and Arrows, they <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>wear Bulls-hides faſhion'd like a Doublet <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>without ſleeves, to defend their Bodies. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Their Chiefs that command over them <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>in War and Peace, are call’d Couracas. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>When they take any one of their Ene<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>mies, alive or dead, they meet all toge<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ther, and after they have reproach'd him, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>that either he or his Relations were the <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>death of their Kindred or Friends, they <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>cut and tear him into pieces, which they <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>roaſt a little and eat, making a drinking <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Bowl of his Scull. They feed moſtly <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>upon flesh either raw or dreſs'd, and <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>particularly Colts fleſh, which they like! <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>better than Veal. They catch abundance <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>of Fiſh likewiſe in their Rivers, They <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>have no ſettled places of aboad, but <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ramble up and down, ſeveral Families <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>together, and live in Tents. 
<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>I could not inform my ſelf exactly <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>what Religion they were of, but I was <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>told that they look'd upon the Sun and <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Moon</tei-p>
</tei-div>
<tei-div data-origname="div"><tei-p data-origname="p">Moon as Deities and as I travell'd along, I ſaw a Savage upon his knees with his Face to the Sun, who cry'd out and made ſtrange geſtures with his Hands and Arms. I learn'd from the Savage that accompany'd me, that he was one of thoſe they call'd Papas, who in the Morning kneel towards the Sun, and at Night towards the Moon, to ſupplicate those fancy'd Divinities to be propitious to them, to give them fair Weather, and Victory over their Foes. 
They make no great Ceremony in their Marriages ; but when a Relation dies, after they have rubb’d his body with a certain Earth that conſumes all but the Bones, they preserve them, and carry as many of them as they can conveniently about with them in a ſort of Cheſts, and this they do in token of their affection to their Kindred ; indeed they are not wanting in good Offices to them during their Lives, nor in their Sickneſs and Death. 
Along the River Salladillo, I took notice of a great many Parrats, or Papagays, as the Spaniards call them, and certain Birds, call’d Guacamayos, which are of divers Colours, and twice or thrice as big as a Parrat. The River it ſelf is full
</tei-p>
</tei-div>
<tei-div data-origname="div"><tei-p data-origname="p">full of the Fiſh, call'd Dorado, which is very good to eat. There is alſo a Creature in it, whether 'tis Meat or Poyſon no body knows, it has Four Feet and a long Tail like a Lizard. 
From Salladillo quite to Cordoua, you go along a very fine River, that abounds with Fiſh, which is neither wide nor deep, for it may be forded over. On the Bank of it you meet with little Plan tations every Three or Four Leagues ; which are like Country Houſes inhabited by Spaniards, Portuguese, and the Natives, who have all the neceſſary accomodations of Life they can wiſh, and are very Civil and Charitable to Strangers; their principal Wealth is in Horſes and Mules, in which they Trade with the Inhabitants of Peru. 
Cordoua is a Town Situate in a pleaſant and fruitful Plain upon the ſide of a River, bigger and broader than that I have juſt ſpoken of : 'Tis compos’d of about 400 Houses, Built like thoſe of Buenos Ayres. It has neither Ditches, nor Walls, nor Fort for its defence; He that Commands it is Governor of all the Provinces of Tucuman, and tho’ it be the place of his ordinary Residence, yet he is wont now and then, as he ſees occaſion, 
</tei-p>
</tei-div>
<tei-div data-origname="div"><tei-p data-origname="p">caſion, to go and paſs ſome time at St. Jago de l’Eſtro, at St. Miguel de Tucuman, (which is the Capital City of the Province) at Salta and at Xuxui. In each of theſe Villages there is a Lieutenant, who has under him an Alcalde and ſome Officers for the Adminiſtration of Juſtice. The Biſhop of Tucuman likewiſe uſually reſides at Cordoua, where the Cathedral is the only Pariſh Church of the whole Town, but there are divers Convents of Monks, namely of Dominicans, Recollects, and those of the Order de la Mercy: and one of Nunns. The Jesuits have a College there, and their Chappel is the fineſt and richeſt of all. 
The Inhabitants are Rich in Gold and Silver, which they get by the Trade they have for Mules, with which they furniſh Peru and other Parts; which is ſo conſiderable, that they ſell about 28 or 30000 of 'em every Year, which they breed up in their Farms. They usually keep 'em till they are about Two Years old, then expose 'em to Sale, and have about Six Patagons a piece for 'em. The Merchants that come to buy 'em, carry 'em to St. Jago, to Salta and Xuxui , where they leave 'em for Three Years, till they are well grown and become ſtrong,
</tei-p>
</tei-div>
<tei-div data-origname="div"><tei-p data-origname="p">ſtrong, and afterwards bring 'em to Peru, where they preſently have Vent for 'em, becauſe there as well as in the reſt of the Western part of America, the greateſt part of their Carriage is upon Mules. The People of Cordoua alſo drive a Trade in Cows, which they have from the Countrey of Buenos Ayres, and carry to Peru, where without this way of Subſiſtance 'tis certain they would have much ado to live. This kind of Traffick makes this Town the moſt conſiderable in the Province of Tucuman, as well for its Riches and Commodities, as for the Number of its Inhabitants, which are counted to be at leaſt 5 or 600 Families, beſides Slaves who are three times the number. But the gene rality of 'em of all degrees have no other Arms but a Sword and Poignard, and are very indifferent Souldiers, the Air of the Country, and the Plenty they enjoy, rendring them Lazy and Cowardly.
</tei-p>
</tei-div>
     </tei-body>
 </tei-text>
